title: Fed Weighs Earlier Stimulus Pullback; U.S. Employers Clamoring for Workers
text:
Top News

Fed Officials See Earlier End for Bond Buying, Emphasize Patience

Fed officials suggested that they might need to pull back their support for the economy sooner than they had anticipated because of stronger-than-expected growth this year. Fed officials discussing the matter at their June 15-16 policy meeting weren't ready to reduce their $120 billion in monthly purchases of Treasury and mortgage securities, according to minutes of the gathering released Wednesday. But an unspecified number thought that time could be approaching.

Fed Officials Continued to Discuss Benefits of a Standing Repo Facility

U.S. Treasury Yields Extend Steep Decline

Bostic Says Time to Taper Is Growing Nearer, but Won't Put Date on It

Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic said that the time is getting closer for the U.S. central bank to pull back on its monthly $120 billion bond-buying stimulus program, but he wouldn't say when that might happen.

Minneapolis Fed Says Vaccines Now Mandatory for Staff

Being vaccinated for Covid-19 is now mandatory at the Minneapolis Fed , its leader, Neel Kashkari, said. "In order to fulfill our public-service mission, we need more face-to-face contact than remote work allows, but there is no way for us to bring a critical mass of our staff back into our facilities and maintain social distancing," Kashkari writes. "Hence, we need our employees to be vaccinated," with exceptions for those with medical or religious issues. (Dow Jones Newswires)

U.S. Economy

U.S. Job Openings Held at Record Level Headed Into Summer

The U.S. Labor Department said job openings rose at the end of May by 16,000, pushing the total to a new high of 9.2 million jobs in records dating back to 2000.

Borrowing Is Back as Sign-Ups for Auto Loans, Credit Cards Hit Records

Americans are borrowing again, in some cases at levels not seen in more than a decade. Consumer demand for auto loans and leases, general-purpose credit cards and personal loans was up 39% in April compared with the same period last year, according to credit-reporting firm Equifax Inc . It was also up 11% compared with April 2019, according to Equifax, which measured how often lenders checked consumers' credit reports to make loan decisions.

Travel Is Bouncing Back Strong, and Airlines Are Racing to Keep Up

Passengers have flocked back to airports more quickly than airlines anticipated, and so have travel headaches like delayed and canceled flights. Industry observers cite staff shortages after too many pilots, mechanics and other workers were let go during the pandemic.

Key Developments Around the World

China's Cabinet Signals RRR Cuts to Support Real Economy

China will use monetary policy tools including cuts in its bank reserve requirement ratio to support the real economy, especially small and midsize enterprises, the State Council said. China will avoid "floodlike" stimulus and keep monetary policy stable and increasingly effective, the cabinet said, to lower financing costs for small and midsize businesses faced with rising commodity prices. China's central bank last cut its RRR in April 2020, unleashing about $56 billion to bolster the country's pandemic-hit economy by slashing small banks' reserve requirements. (Dow Jones Newswires)

Malaysia Central Bank Holds Policy Rate After Renewed Lockdown

Malaysia's central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Thursday after the imposition of stricter measures last week to tackle the spread of Covid-19. Bank Negara Malaysia held its overnight policy rate at 1.75%, as predicted by 16 economists polled by WSJ.

Bank of Canada Expected to Announce Further QE Taper Next Week

The Bank of Canada will likely announce a further reduction in its quantitative-easing program at a scheduled announcement next week, Capital Economics economist Stephen Brown says.

Canada's economic performance has broadly matched the central bank's April forecast, Brown says. At the same time, inflation is well above target. CapEcon anticipates a reduction in Canadian government bond purchases to 2 billion Canadian dollars a week, down from the current C$3 billion, followed by another reduction in October and an end to the program before 2022. (DJN)

Glynn's Take: Economic Case for Reopening Australia to the World Is Getting Louder

By James Glynn

The economic case for reopening Australia's international border to skilled workers is gaining increasing momentum, but as lockdowns keep shuttering major cities, the politically prickly issue might not be acted upon with any vigor until after the next federal election that is due within the next year. Read More.

Financial Regulation Roundup

Robinhood Debut Clouded by SEC Scrutiny of Payment for Order Flow

Robinhood Markets is on a collision course with regulators over a controversial practice that generates most of its revenue, as the online brokerage gears up for a highly anticipated initial public offering.

Former Enron Executive: Whistleblower Program Is a Game Changer

Sherron Watkins, the Enron executive who warned management about fraud, said not having confidentiality and protection for whistleblowers can have a cost.

Nearly 20 years after the energy company's collapse, Ms. Watkins said being labeled a whistleblower has been a challenge to her career ever since. If current whistleblower protections had been in place at the time, she said she would have been able to report her concerns to the SEC while keeping her name confidential.

Commentary

America's Stocks Have Lost Their Exceptionalism (Except Big Tech)

"It is extraordinary to find that America's banks and industrial stocks now move more closely with foreign share prices than with U.S. growth stocks, which are dominated by the FANGs— Facebook , Amazon, Netflix and Google , now Alphabet—along with Microsoft ," writes The Wall Street Journal's James Mackintosh in a Streetwise column. "The big change driving the past year's extreme divergence in daily swings is the increased sensitivity to actions of the government and central bank," he says, concluding: "What seems wrong is that in a free market stocks should be so dependent on government and central-bank action. Given the unprecedented scale of intervention, perhaps it is only to be expected. My fear is that, unlike many of the effects of Covid-19, this dynamic is here to stay."

Basis Points

Behind the standoff inside OPEC over whether to boost oil production is a key cartel member with a new strategy: sell as much crude as possible before demand dries up. The United Arab Emirates's strategy represents one of the most significant shifts in oil policy by a major Mideast petrostate.

Ketchum, Idaho, has plenty of available jobs, but workers can't afford housing.

Mexico produced 264.000 cars and light trucks in June, 5.5% more than in the year-earlier month, while exports rose 18% to 234,000 units, statistics institute Inegi reports. (Dow Jones Newswires)

Mainland Norwegian GDP expanded 1.8% month-on-month in May, helped by the reopening of shops and malls. Capital Economics says the jump was twice as large as the consensus forecast and will confirm to the central bank that tighter policy is needed. (DJN)
